snippet: As Wladimir Balentien closes in on a single-season home run record of 55, first set by Sadaharu Oh, many fans are now rooting for Oh’s record to fall, a development that once seemed unthinkable.
abstract: Japanese culture of deference to baseball legend Sadaharu Oh has seemingly ended as many fans are rooting for his record of 55 home runs in single season to fall; Wladimir Balentien, playing for Tokyo Yakult Swallows, may soon surpass Oh's record; younger generation of Japanese is seen as more comfortable than ever with notion of knocking off national heroes.

byline.original: By HIROKO TABUCHI and JOSHUA HUNT

lead_paragraph: As Wladimir Balentien closes in on a single-season home run record of 55, first set by Sadaharu Oh, many fans are now rooting for Oh’s record to fall, a development that once seemed unthinkable.

headline.main: Deference to a Revered Record in Japan Is Going, Going ...
headline.print_headline: Deference to a Revered Record In Japan Is Going, Going ...
